    • CloudAudit Definitions
    • Cloudtrail
      • Cloudtrail service not enabled
      • Global Cloudtrail not enabled
    • EC2
      • TCP port open
      • Security Group contains IP address
      • Security group contains a port range
      • Security group allows unrestricted traffic
    • ELB
      • ELB using old SSL policy
      • ELB using most current SSL policy
      • Classic ELB Inventory
    • IAM
      • Active user Access Key not rotated
      • Passwords not set to expire
      • Inactive user Access Key not rotated
      • Password policy doesn't exist
      • Multiple active access keys
      • MFA not enabled
      • Root MFA not enabled
      • Root user has active password
      • Root user has active Access Key
      • Users can reuse old passwords
      • Unused or empty IAM group
      • Account using inline policies
    • RDS
      • RDS is Publicly Accessible
      • RDS short backup retention
      • RDS no automatic upgrades
    • Redshift
      • Cluster data not encrypted
      • Redshift connections not SSL
      • User activity logging disabled
      • Automatic upgrades not enabled
      • Cluster is publicly accessible
      • Redshift TCP port open
    • S3
      • All users can list bucket
      • All users can write to bucket
      • All users can change bucket permissions
      • All AWS users can read bucket
      • All AWS users can change bucket permissions
      • All AWS users can write to bucket
      • Bucket logging not enabled
      • Bucket policy uses IP addresses
      • Bucket policy world All permissions
      • Bucket policy world can Delete
      • Bucket policy world can Get
      • Bucket policy world can List
      • Bucket policy world can Put

    Bucket policy gives world Get, Put, List, and Delete permission

    Bucket policy allows the world to get, put, list, and delete the affected bucket.
    Edit me

    Details

    The bucket policy allows the world to get, put, list, delete the affected bucket. S3 bucket policies are a type of access control list but are different than S3 ACLs. S3 bucket policies specify what actions are allowed or denied for which principals on the bucket that the bucket policy is attached to. You attach S3 bucket policies at the bucket level, but the permissions specified in the bucket policy apply to all the objects in the bucket.

    An S3 Bucket Policy has been added that grants public access to your bucket. Get, put, list, and delete access has been granted to the world on the affected bucket. This allows anyone to get, put, list, and delete your bucket content. You can use bucket policies to grant permissions to individual AWS accounts; however, it is strongly recommended that you do not grant public access to your bucket unless you are absolutely certain. Consider alternative methods to provide public access to your buckets.
    https://aws.amazon.com/articles/5050
    https://blogs.aws.amazon.com/security/post/TxPOJBY6FE360K/IAM-policies-and-Bucket-Policies-and-ACLs-Oh-My-Controlling-Access-to-S3-Resourc

    Suggested Action

    Remove the bucket permission that enables the world to get, put, list, and delete the contents of this bucket. See Updating ACL to Remove Public Access to Your Buckets

    Additional Information

    See Alternatives to Public Access for more information.

    To learn more about ACLs, see the following topics in Amazon S3 Developer Guide.
    Access Control List (ACL) Overview
    Managing ACLs in the AWS Management Console
